This month we are asking for your support through 
our premium programs via The Escapist Plus and

YouTube Memberships. Your support allows us to 
continue making the content we want instead of

chasing algorithms or the latest trends. Plus, you 
get a bunch of perks like ad free viewing via The

Escapist Plus on our website, early access on 
YouTube via YouTube Memberships, and bonus content

like our monthly Ask the Creators video series 
were we answer your burning questions. We&#39;ve also

added three new perks to our $5 tier. Including 
a 15% discount on merch via our Teespring shop,

a new piece of bonus content called Escapist 
Highlights; featuring the best moment from our

stream each month. And, a new members only 
live stream - The State of the Escapist,

where you get a quarterly update on how the 
site is doing from our Editor in Chief. New

merch is now also available from Adventure is 
Nigh, Zero Punctuation, and more. Thanks to our

fans continuing support The Escapist is on track 
for our best year yet! Was that slow enough Nick?

There&#39;s a lot you can get done in 12 minutes. 
Walk the dog. Learn a new fact about the moon.

Listen to an entire ad break on a commercial radio 
station. I, for example, can use twelve minutes to

extinguish all your enthusiasm for a recent game 
you thought might have been interesting. Er. As

long as you watch this video twice. So 
not too long ago I did The Forgotten City,

assuming you haven&#39;t. Forgotten. And I said at the 
time that time loops are becoming a trend amid a

certain breed of narrative-driven adventure game. 
It wasn&#39;t a proper trend yet because it was only

indie games doing it. When something with some 
real money behind it rips it off and acts like

they invented the fucking concept, that&#39;s when 
you know a trend has hit the big time. 12 Minutes

certains seems to have a not insignificant amount 
of money to swan about with. Daisy Ridley money,

no less. Yes, that hot young starlet best known 
for her showstopping turns as &quot;the posh girl

from the new Star Wars&quot; and... well anyway. James 
McAvoy and Willem DaFoe are here too to crank the

star power up even higher and guess what? If the 
game hadn&#39;t told me that big celebrities did the

voices, I wouldn&#39;t have been able to fucking 
tell. So not for the first time I have to ask

a video game what on earth the fucking point of 
hiring that kind of expensive talent was if any

jobbing voice overer could have achieved the 
same result. I guess Willem DaFoe&#39;s voice has

a unique character to it - although in this case 
he seems to be doing his best Christopher Lloyd

impression - but the other two are both putting 
on American accents and just sound like generic

actor persons the casting director could have 
bundled into a van at literally any Los Angeles

bus stop. I mean, you only hired them so you 
could slap their names on the front, why make

them talk in an accent that makes them doubly 
unrecognisable? It&#39;s like getting a personalised

number plate with a non-obvious meaning. You blew 
all that money and didn&#39;t even gain any status,

you&#39;ve just made the dude behind you squint in 
confusion at your bumper. This is a very minor

point to harp on for so long, Yahtzee, it almost 
seems like there isn&#39;t much to say about the game.

Oh look it&#39;s Captain Observant everyone. He must 
have been let out early from his job pointing out

the spelling mistakes in other people&#39;s Reddit 
posts. Yeah, it&#39;s a snacky, student short film

of a game about a twelve minute sequence taking 
place in three rooms. It&#39;s not what you&#39;d call

bingeable. The premise is, you&#39;re a dude who 
comes home to his lazy-arse wife who thinks

getting two store-bought chocolate lava cakes 
out of the fridge counts as &quot;cooking dinner&quot;,

after which a very angry man bursts in and, in 
brief summary, fucks the pair of you up. Then

you get inexplicably transported back ten minutes 
and keep getting sent back to that moment every

time you die or attempt to leave the apartment. 
Our hero must repeat the loop until he can avert

his fate and eventually get to the bottom of 
the various dark secrets that are lurking under

everything like a dead spider in a carelessly 
poured glass of milk. I like the presentation.

The harsh, directly top down camera angle creates 
an effective sense of foreboding, like we the

player are the sword of Damocles waiting to stab 
our character&#39;s pleasant evening with the missus

right when he&#39;s assessing his blowjob chances. The 
attention to detail with the number of things you

can do and that other characters will react to is 
- well I suppose it would&#39;ve been more impressive

if there were more than three fucking rooms in 
the game. But hey, I can steal my wife&#39;s phone

and hide it in the ventilation duct and put 
candles around it like I&#39;m leaving an offering

to the god of HVAC engineering and that&#39;s got 
to count for something. I found 12 Minutes to

be absorbing up to a point. The home invasion is 
kinda harrowing at first, but it&#39;s interesting how

desensitised you get after a few goes around. Hm, 
looks like jumping out of the closet and handing

the home invader dessert doesn&#39;t do anything, ho 
hum, guess I&#39;ll let him shatter my jawbone against

a chair leg again. It&#39;s probably saying something 
terribly profound about cycles of violence and our

desensitisation to horror in modern society. But 
then the game takes a turn. And I should probably

drop a spoiler warning here because people 
always jump up my butt if I don&#39;t, so here goes:

spoiler warning, my butt is not open to callers 
today thank you. There&#39;s a moment where you think

you&#39;ve got it all figured out. You deescalate the 
home invasion, the burglar says he&#39;s very sorry,

everyone agrees to part amicably with a party bag 
and a slice of birthday cake, you and your wife

embrace lovingly and then BAM it&#39;s ten minutes 
ago again and you&#39;re standing nonplussed at the

front door with your big relieved stiffy hanging 
unfulfilled like an unpulled fire alarm at a

remedial school. This is the bit where the game 
effectively channels the middle act of Groundhog

Day, when we and the protagonist start trying 
everything to figure out what this fucking time

loop even wants from us. Get the happy ending 
again but with slight changes in details - nope.

Fix it so the invader never shows up at all 
and have a perfectly nice evening in with the

oblivious wife - nope. Murder the home invader, 
then murder my wife then murder myself in the

face with a gun - nope. Wasn&#39;t actually expecting 
that to work, but I was bloody disappointed there

wasn&#39;t an achievement for it. This was all very 
intriguing, but only until I found the final

twist before the ending-ending, at which point 
the game kinda fell apart. I think it was the

ending-ending. I&#39;ve consulted with a number of 
colleagues and we&#39;re all only tentatively sure

it was the ending. There was certainly a credits 
sequence - in which I spotted a credit for Daisy

Ridley&#39;s voice coach, more needless expense, 
was this a fucking tax thing, guys - but there

was still a sense of anticlimax. I won&#39;t spoil 
the last twist, but for the sake of discussion

I&#39;ll replace it with something roughly equivalent: 
after you connect the last dot, it turns out that

all along the main character was a dog molester. 
And the only way to escape the time loop is to get

the game to go &quot;You know what, let&#39;s just wash 
our hands of this whole affair and pretend it

never happened.&quot; And in reply I go &quot;Well, yes, 
I suppose that would be for the best. Honestly

I&#39;m a little bewildered as to how it happened in 
the first place. I mean, why would a dog molester

marry a human woman? You&#39;d think they&#39;d want to 
settle down with a nice homely golden retriever.

But I still get this nagging sense that I got 
the unsatisfying bad ending that leaves things

unresolved and there must be some good ending you 
can get somehow where you escape the time loop

with your wife and she comes to terms with you 
wanting to bugger spaniels and you live happily

ever after in a house that backs onto the local 
animal shelter, but that wouldn&#39;t work because

we fucking molest dogs. So I&#39;m left trapped in 
this confused mental limbo between wanting some

closure for the character we&#39;ve been identifying 
with all this time and his long-suffering wife

and not wanting to encourage the rape of 
chihuahuas. But I don&#39;t know if I&#39;d call

12 Minutes good or bad. It&#39;s just... weird. It&#39;s 
not bland 5 material either, because it at least

sparks conversation. Even if that conversation 
is &quot;get the fuck away from my labradoodle.&quot;
